author: .paulharris
content:
i had put some thoughts on the eip discussion thread... 
 - concerned about churn increase because we havent addressed the reasons we reduced deposit rate
 - questioning the value of consolidation as a pathway because fairness and complexity

author: sproul
content: it's already possible to send exits via the consolidation queue using this "submarine" technique: <https://piertwo.com/insights/introducing-submarine-accelerated-eth-withdrawals-via-consolidation>. It's kind of nice if EIP-8061 can obsolete that by providing the same thing in a way that is simpler & fairer (doesn't require validators to use a whale validator/specific staking provider's service)

author: greystroke
content: This seems like a design oversight. Better idea, fix this loophole by making it an invalid operation if consolidating increases the total staked ETH to over the 2048 ETH threshold. Then we can forget about Eip-8061.

author: fradamt
content: Another proposed EIP does that already. Not sure how it follows that "we can forget about EIP-8061"

author: fradamt
content:
1) I am going to update the EIP to keep the deposit cap. Does that satisfy your concern?
2) However keeping the deposit cap means we have to push for the consolidation path to be used, otherwise consolidation will be way too slow

author: fradamt
content: And sorry, decided to post here instead of ethmagicians because I'd like to get these changes in before the next call and I am not confident most people check ethmagicians much. Thanks for commenting there as well

author: fradamt
content: Right, this would also obsolete EIP-8071

author: sproul
content: ta, hadn't seen that specific EIP

author: fradamt
content: Any concerns about that specific way of doing the dual usage? I can't think of a simpler one than just directly re-routing

author: .paulharris
content:
so not unwinding the limit on deposits is probably wise, doesnt open us back up to the original problem...

im not sure we want preferential treatment of consolidation, but then equally we're back to having an issue with deposits if the consolidation queue isn't a thing, so i'm not sure what's best honestly :/

author: fradamt
content: What do you mean by preferential treatment of consolidations? The above lets exits use the consolidation queue, but not the opposite

author: .paulharris
content: I just mean in the current state of play there’s preference as it’s the one that gets the size increases as we scale. I’m not against exits being able to take space there

author: fradamt
content: Ah I see. EIP-8061 does propose to restore exit churn also scaling proportionally to the total stake

author: potuz
content: Just want to mention that depositing above 2048ETH or consolidating to above 2048 ETH may be desirable for some builders

author: fradamt
content: Regardless of that, how would that work? The current spec does not exempt 0x03 from the sweep, does it?

author: potuz
content: no it doesn't, we talked a while back to removing the sweep from 0x03 validators, but decided to leave that discussion for later until we have a bettter understanding of what builders will do
